title: In the movie, the Sorcerer’s Stone, why didn't Dumbledore do something when he saw Harry Potter’s broom was bewitched during Quidditch? - Quora
tags: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001 movie)

response.answer_text: You mean the scene where Hermione burned Snape's robe? Well easy. The answer is Dumbledore knows that Snape is protecting Harry. There is no point in Dumbledore participating as Snape is a fully capable powerful wizard as well. If Dumbledore to stand up and check it on person, it will attract everybody's attention, and may or may not create panic/chaos, the perpetrator will stop their business and blend right in into the crowd. If a great man needs to come and save the day everytime he sees something wrong then he'll spend his day rescuing people non stop.

“Snape was trying to save me?” “Of course,” said Quirrell coolly. “Why do you think he wanted to referee your next match? He was trying to make sure I didn’t do it again. Funny, really . . . he needn’t have bothered. I couldn’t do anything with Dumbledore watching. All the other teachers thought Snape was trying to stop Gryffindor from winning, he did make himself unpopular . . . and what a waste of time, when after all that, I’m going to kill you tonight.” Above is a part of conversation between Harry and Quirrell in the book ‘Harry Potter and the Socerer’s Stone’.
